title: Philippe Brunel
text:
Philippe Brunel (born 28 February 1973) is a French former professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>. He was a midfielder or playmaker with a wide range of passing.
Career.
Lens.
Brunel began his career at <a href="RC%20Lens">RC Lens</a> in 1991. From then until 1995, he made 27 appearances for the club, scoring one goal before moving to <a href="FC%20Gueugnon">FC Gueugnon</a> on a year-long loan in 1995. He made 34 appearances and scored 4 goals for Gueugnon; upon the completion of his loan, he returned to Lens.
Upon his return, Brunel featured much more prominently in the Lens squad; over five years from 1996 to 2001, he played 131 times and scored 8 goals in <a href="Ligue%201">Ligue 1</a>. He contributed 33 appearances as his side won <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20French%20Division%201">1997–98 French Division 1</a>. The following season he played as a substitute in the final as they won the <a href="1999%20Coupe%20de%20la%20Ligue%20Final">1998-99 Coupe de la Ligue</a>. He also featured in the club's <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> campaign in the 1999–2000 season, making two appearances - a 1–2 defeat to <a href="1.%20FC%20Kaiserslautern">1. FC Kaiserslautern</a> on 25 November 1999 in the home leg of the 3rd-round tie, and the 1–4 victory in the away leg.
Marseille.
Brunel's performances for Lens earned him a free transfer in 2001 to <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Olympique de Marseille</a>, however as with his time at Gueugnon his Marseille career did not go to plan; having made only 11 appearances for his new club, he was transferred in January 2002 to <a href="Lille%20OSC">Lille</a> for £880,000.
Lille.
During the second half of the season, Brunel made a further 11 appearances for Lille, scoring once, in addition to two appearances in the UEFA Cup - both legs of the last-16 tie with <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a> on 21 and 28 February 2002.
From then until 2005, he would make a total of 118 appearances for Lille and score 16 goals in the process; in 2005 he was transferred to <a href="FC%20Sochaux-Montb%C3%A9liard">Sochaux</a>, however he made only 28 appearances in two years with the club before leaving for <a href="Angers%20SCO">Angers SCO</a> in 2007. While at Sochaux he played as a substitute as they won the <a href="2007%20Coupe%20de%20France%20Final">2007 Coupe de France Final</a>. The game finished 2-2 and went to penalties, and Brunel scored his penalty in the shootout as his side emerged victorious.
Angers.
Over four years with Angers, Brunel scored 10 goals in a total of 99 league appearances in <a href="Ligue%202">Ligue 2</a>; having featured regularly until 2010 but not made a single appearance in the 2010–11 season, he retired from professional football and moved into amateur football with <a href="AS%20Valence">AS Valence</a> in the summer of 2011.
Honours.
Lens
Lille
Sochaux
